text.p: The following are top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Singapore Housing Board will continue granting rental concessions to about 95 percent of its commercial and industrial tenants when tenancy terms come up for renewal.
- Singapore Minister for Foreign Affairs S. Jayakumar says destinies of Singapore and Australia 'are inextricably linked' to each other.
- Revenue authorities collected Singapore $36.5 million from tax defaulters and others through courts and $2.4 million from fines for late filing.
- Asian airlines scorched by rising global jet-fuel prices.
- Major shareholder Parry Chang of Electro-Magnetics (1992) has no intentions of selling his 60 million warrants which will expire on Friday.
- Malaysian car maker Proton and controlling shareholder, Yahaya Ahmad buy 80 percent stake in British sportscar maker Lotus for 51 million sterling.
- Sterling surges and shares tumbles on London stock market following a quarter-point hike in country's bank rate to 6 percent.
- Major Taiwanese companies have overseas investments plans on hold or axed following government's moratorium on new investments overseas by state-run companies.
- Malayan Credit Ltd clinches Robertson Quay site, last remaining freehold area along Singapore River, for Singapore $128.89 million.
- Canadian gold mining company Bre-X Minerals' shares soar after deal with Sigit Harjojudanto.
- Deutsche Telekom will list its shares on the Singapore bourse if demand proves strong in Asia.
